div1.head: Jim to Mlle. Marcelle Guerin Apr 1915
div1.p: We have just received orders to proceed to Pont a Mousson to morrow at nine. We will arrive there probably at noon. It is at the front and our letters will be held for several days, so I am taking this opportunity of writing.

Our squad is most fortunate. It is the first to go to the front. This morning our roll was called and we were asked for an address to notify in case we we [sic] were wounded or killed. It really promises to be interesting and worth while work and I am very glad.

The fact that I am on this squad, a squad whose members were chosen carefully, should convince you that your fear of my breaking loose is ungrounded. I liked you for telling me frankly not to kick over the traces and to watch myself, but honestly I never fall down on a job. Why after our squad was complete, three men were ordered dropped, and I still remained, so you see my record isn’t so rotten.

We’ve had the most wonderful trip imaginable.
After threading our way across Paris, and jolting along the rough cobblestone streets of the outskirts, we found ourselves traveling along a perfect road through the most charming country. You know how pleasing it is; the exquisite coloring that is on every hand; the great stretches of undulating ground divided into the angular patch work fields, that are in themselves delightful gardens; the quaint, artistic groups of houses that cluster along the ribbon like road, and the light green streams that delineate the curving valleys. Never have I felt that life was so pretty or the world so good. I am aware now of what is meant by “La Belle France” as I never was before. Why I wouldn’t trade one of the vistas I saw our second day out, as we followed the Marne, for the whole of Paris. Somehow I associated all of it with you much more than I do Paris. It would have seemed much more natural to meet you out there than to encounter you in Paris. Its all so free, and beautiful and sweet that it seems as if that should comprise your surroundings rather that the artificial atmosphere of the city.

We passed through many places where fighting had taken place. At noon we had reached La Ferte Gaucher where the battle
that drove the Germans back commenced. A little further on we passed numerous graves. Some were quite elaborate and had permanent crosses and wreathes on them. These were along the road and sheltered many soldiers, while others out in the fields were marked with a rude cross only, save when the poor fellow’s kepi had been placed on the top. The fields are being cultivated now and the furrows run almost to the little spot of ground in which the cross is placed. Beyond we went through little villages where a number of houses had been levelled [sic] by shell fire, and some had burnt.

Our first night out we stopped at St. Dizier where the population turned out and crowded around our cars. I’d have you know that I’m getting on so well in French that I was able to answer
all their questions and had a group all of my own. Curtin had another of course.

This place is quite dead. All the fine hotels have been turned into hospitals and only soldiers are about. A very quaint place down in the village and most interesting. The air here is great and gives one really too great an appetite for satisfying on the army rations. We’re under military rule now. Have to salute, be in at eight, and obey all kinds of rules. Our Captain here is a fine fellow. Hope the next one’s the same.
You’ll write me won’t you? And soon for I’m terribly anxious to hear from you. I’ll send you word from our new post as soon as possible.
